attributes.alt: Cover for Hooray for Hoppy! by Tim Hopgood. Cover shows a rabbit smelling flowers in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
How does Hoppy know spring has sprung?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, pointing out opportunities to count.
Understand that items and amounts can be counted; Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.
Count objects for children, pointing to each as you count.
Challenge children to spot mistakes you deliberately make when counting.
What can we learn from using our senses?
What senses are used in this story?
Can you pretend it is spring? What will you do on this beautiful spring day?
How many cubes are here? How can you tell?
How do you know when it is spring?
Can you make a rabbit like Hoppy?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word
Make a tower with blocks. How many blocks did you use?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to talk about feelings and review counting with one-to-one correspondence.
Understand that items and amounts can be counted; Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Challenge children to guess the number of cubes you have hidden.
Count the cubes and compare the amount to the guesses.
Discuss children’s feelings about the results.
What can we learn from using our senses?
What senses do you use when you read a book?
What emotions can you pretend to have? How will you show them?
How many of one thing can you count?
What can you write that tells about one of the five senses?
Can you make a face showing an emotion?
Can you spell your first name with magnetic letters?

attributes.alt: Cover for Hooray for Hoppy! by Tim Hopgood. Cover shows a rabbit smelling flowers in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to review ordinal terms, play a game, and introduce vocabulary
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to practice ordinal counting.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Understand that items and amounts can be counted; Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence; Correctly use ordinal terms, including first through fifth, next, and last.
Use perception to guide movement through space and interactions with objects and people.
Guide children to line up and pretend to be rabbits having a parade.
Have children identify their positions in the line using ordinal terms.
What can we learn from using our senses?
What senses do you use when you listen to a story?
Pretend to be playing outside. How do you use your senses?
Arrange Connecting Cubes in a row. Which cubes are first, second, and last?
Can your write about something that happens in an order? What happens first? Last?
Make a picture of your favorite season.
What letters do you see in the word
Build a train using three different kinds of blocks. Which block is first, which is second, and which is last?

attributes.alt:
Big Chart of Big Ideas for See! Hear! Taste! Smell! And Touch! Chart shows a young boy with arrows pointing to different senses.
Bubbles point to different parts of the boy’s body:
-   Bubble next to boy’s eye says "What can I use my eyes to see?"
-   Bubble next to boy’s tongue says "What can I use my tongue to taste?"-   Bubble next to boy’s nose says "What can I use my nose to smell?"
-   Bubble next to boy’s ear says "What can I use my ears to hear?"
-   Bubble next to boy’s hand says "What can I use my hand to touch?"

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas: See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch!

attributes.alt: Cover for Hooray for Hoppy! by Tim Hopgood. Cover shows a rabbit smelling flowers in the grass.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to review the order of counting, play a game with senses, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
See! Hear! Taste! Smell! and Touch!
Read interactively and connect to counting with senses.

Understand that items and amounts can be counted; Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence; Correctly use ordinal terms, including first through fifth, next, and last; Recognize and name numerals 0–9.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Connect numerals to number words and quantities.
Challenge children to match numeral images to their names.
Have children match names to numerals.
What can we learn from using our senses?
How do you feel about that book?
How can you pretend to taste and smell some yummy food?
How many ways can you show the number five?
Write about something you noticed with one of your senses. Which sense did you use?
Can you create something that tells about one of the five senses?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of
Can you build something out of only five pieces? What can you make?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to connect the book to literacy, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary
Start Story Time by revisiting the book
What can Hoppy learn using his senses?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on counting.
Understand that items and amounts can be counted; Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence; Recognize and name numerals 0–9.
Support children as they independently respond to the prompt:
How do you use your senses to learn about the world? How many senses do you use?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What can we learn from using our senses?
Which of the five senses are strongest in this book?
Pretend it is the first day of spring. What does it look like? What does it feel like?
What do you want to learn about? How can you use your senses to learn more about that?
Write about something you can see or touch.
Can you make one of the body parts we use with our five senses?
What letter do you hear at the start of
Can you build something that is made out of exactly eight pieces? What will you build?
